comment._content:

comment.author: 69755091@N07
comment._content: Douglas George Adams. Medal Index Card shows he arrived in France on the 14th March 1915.

comment.author: 38811045@N04
comment._content: Note that the service number 300432 belongs to the series issued to the 5th (City of London) Battalion, The London Regiment (London Rifle Brigade) in early 1917. This battalion is confirmed on L/Cpl Adam's entry in Soldiers Died in The Great War. Lance-Corporal Adams' original number with the 5th Londons was 521 and he joined the battalion in the first week of September 1914. Aftre the action on 1st July 1916 he was presumably posted as missing in action and wouldn have still officially been noted as missing in 1917 when the Territorial Force was re-numbered. This explains why he was given a new number in early 1917, even though he had, by that time, been dead for five or six months. For regimental number information about the 5th Londons see: armyservicenumbers.blogspot.com/2008/08/5th-city-of-londo...

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: In 1901 the Adamses lived at 39 Bartholomew Road, St Pancras maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.r_qf... Mr Adams had his own Grocer's business. In 1911 the family were living at 39 Holmdene Avenue, Herne Hill, London maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.r_qf... and Douglas was a 15yr old schoolboy. His father, Charles, was now a Florist Buyer for Stores and had been married to Louise Maria for 18yrs. They had had only 2 children: Douglas and his older brother Ernest Charles who, at 17, was working as an Electrician Assistant. The family employed 17yr old Maggie Ryder as a Domestic Servant.
